meanings.def: popular music of the sort that has been popular since the 1950s, usually with a strong rhythm and simple tunes, often contrasted with rock, soul and other forms of popular music
examples: rock, pop and soul
The album covers a range of genres—from mainstream pop to jazz.

meanings.def: a short, sharp, explosive sound
examples: The cork came out of the bottle with a loud pop.

meanings.def: a sweet fizzy drink (= with bubbles) that is not alcoholic
used as a word for ‘father’, especially as a form of address
examples: Hi, Pop!

meanings.def: to attack somebody physically or in words
examples: Football managers are always taking a pop at referees.

meanings.def: costing a particular amount for each one
examples: We can charge $50 a pop.

idioms.def: to attack somebody physically or in words
examples: Football managers are always taking a pop at referees.

idioms.def: costing a particular amount for each one
examples: We can charge $50 a pop.

meanings.def: connected with modern popular music
examples: a pop song
a pop star/singer
a pop band/group
a pop concert
the pop charts

meanings.def: made in a modern popular style
examples: pop culture

meanings.def: to make a short explosive sound; to cause something to make this sound
examples: the sound of corks popping
Flashbulbs were popping all around them.
pop something He popped the cork on the champagne bottle.

meanings.def: to burst, or make something burst (= break apart or open), with a short explosive sound
examples: She jumped as someone popped a balloon behind her.

meanings.def: to go somewhere quickly, suddenly or for a short time
examples: I'll pop over and see you this evening.
Why don't you pop in (= visit us) for a drink next time you're in the area?
He's just popped out of the office for a few minutes.
I'm just popping down to the shops.

meanings.def: to put something/somebody somewhere quickly, suddenly or for a short time
examples: He popped his head around the door and said hello.
I'll pop the books in (= deliver them) on my way home.
Pop your bag on here.

meanings.def: to suddenly appear, especially when not expected
examples: The window opened and a dog's head popped out.
An idea suddenly popped into his head.
(computing) The dialog box pops up every time I try to close the browser.
A number of small objects suddenly popped into view.
The yellow flowers were popping up all over the garden.
Crabs occasionally pop out of holes in the sand.
A small jazz band had popped out of nowhere.

meanings.def: if your ears pop when you are going up or down in a plane, etc., the pressure in them suddenly changes
if your eyes pop or pop out, they suddenly open fully because you are surprised or excited
examples: Her eyes nearly popped out of her head when she saw them.

meanings.def: to take a lot of a drug, regularly
examples: She's been popping pills for months.

meanings.def: to open the bonnet of a car
to die
to ask somebody to marry you

idioms.def: to ask somebody to marry you

meanings.def: to burst (= to break open) or explode with a sudden short sound
examples: The balloon went pop.
If you eat any more, you’ll go pop!

idioms.def: to burst (= to break open) or explode with a sudden short sound
examples: The balloon went pop.
If you eat any more, you’ll go pop!

meanings.def: population
